feedback: Good to learn that you can do loops in the command line; didn't know that before.
For loops were explained very well.  Section was interesting.
Loop was very interesting.
The challenges.  Exercises are engaging.
Having helpers around is very important otherwise I'd definitely be lost.
Easy to follow.  Loved seeing commands on the screen.  Exercises were helpful.  Shorcuts were great to learn.
It was helpful to type out all the commands with the instructor to get a better idea of how the program works.
Great explanations of functionality of different operators.
Learning basic Linux commands in a formal setting was very helpful and will save time in future.
I liked how everyone could follow along.  Other people's questions helped me too.
Explained very clearly.  Got to try it on your own.
Step by step instruction.
I like the explanations of what each command is and what is is doing / what it means.
Interactive activities have been very helpful.  I especially feel like the pipe examples were very clear.
Liked the teaching style using exercises, especially using files in different places to practice navigation.
Easy to follow.  Content is simple and straight forward.  I can actually learn useful things in workshop (sic).
I liked learning using the shell commands because I use the shell a lot and didn't know some shortcuts i.e. ctrl+a.
Learning how to use unix to navigate and create files.  Using word count and sort, head, tail, functions to display data in a convenient way.  Liked the exercises to check I know what I am diong.
I liked following along and watching someone else do actual code.  Access to the lessons and problems are helpful.
The exercises are a very useful / effective way to learn the commands.

I am really enjoying this workshop as I never learned coding before so anything is better than nothing.  However from a learning perspective I really like the green and red post-it idea as I think that was pretty clever.
Great crash course on Unix command line.  It was a good revision for those who are familiar with the content.
Challenge problems.  Software Carpentry website with all notes.  Green and red post-it system.  Instructor walking through each line and what all symbols mean.
Everything, including the pace, has been great so far.
Nice explanation of the material.  Good UI.
The tutorial was easy to follow.  I came in with no background in computer science but I was still able to follow along.  Thank you.
Jupyter notebook is awesome.  Shared Carpentries pad.  Examples from GitHub.  Going over basic commands.

Some abbreviations I still don't get.  I know I an Google / check the manual but it would be nice if there was more reiteration of what the '$' is, or what '..' vs '.' does.  I don't get the real world application of some of this; to be fair though I know nothing about computer science.
Would like more background on what is the Shell vs Python.
I wish there was more information on what the Unix shell is used for in daily practice and how it could be applicable to me.
Can't see the bottom of the screen from the back of the room; harder to follow.
Would have liked more context behind what we were doing.
Many terms and computer talk used that may be foreign to others.  Also what is the significance of this stuff?
Not detailed enough when talking about loops; got lost figuring out what the loop is doing.
Don't understand '|' vs '>' vs '>>' very well; might need to go more in detail with that.
Maybe do more exercises and quicker, or do them together.
I don't like how it was hard to see what was being input because it was at the bottom of the screen.
Clear more often.  Move window up; can't see what you are typing.  More context: what is a directory / are these files actually on my computer?  Alsi is this python another program?
echo doesn't need '' even when space is involved.
Maybe give some more time for explanations.
We went a bit slow at times on topics that were relatively easy to understand (basic commands).
The most basic things can be gone through faster or skipped.
Sometimes it went too fast and got a little confusing.
Some commands glossed over too quicky and hard to follow.
As someone with no coding experience, some of it went a little fast, and I could have used more actuall recall.
Really still unsure about the remove functions and accidentally deleting files / directories.  Go slower and more examples.
The pacing was overall slow; could spend less time on the exercises.

I think having a 'cheat sheet' with the basic commands would have made the beginning go faster.  Doing larger problems / utilizing more commands at once would have better facilitated my understanding of how to use them.  Would have liked to learn how to write scripts using notepad.
Pace was a bit too slow in the beginning and rushed at the end.
Want to cover everything.
It's moving pretty quickly but I've been okay so far.  Maybe incorporate more real world applications of what this could be used for.
